title.narrative: Philippines : Anticipatory Action for Lahar Risks - START Funded

description.narrative: After three months, barangays and local government units, and civil society organisations in Albay are more prepared to avoid the devastating impacts of lahar risks. Local disaster authorities have higher lahar risk monitoring capacity and have developed preparedness and response plans that are informed by scientifically verified and community-validated risk information that. Evacuation processes will be more systematic and authorities will have better capacity to manage the costs to cover the needs of displaced population because of finer lahar map models which provides detailed information for priority areas of evacuation. Families and communities in the areas are more informed of their risk situation, has the capacity to prepare for foreseen risks at household level, take part in risk reduction activities and are more cooperative to government authorities in all phases of disaster.

Lahar can potentially displace up to 90,000 residents from nine municipalities and two cities. Barangays from low lying areas and communities along river channels are at risk of inundation or overflowing of large segments of lahar and washout or erosion of land surfaces due to the sudden downpour of lahar. Trees, roads, infrastructure can be buried under several meters of lahar flows. Continuous and strong rain can wash away ash and heavy rock deposits and boulders coming from volcanic eruptions including old rock deposits can be mobilized along river streams and river channels. In the event of lahar, the most vulnerable members of the three barangays including pregnant women, children, elderly persons and persons with disabilities tend to be disproportionately affected.
